explanations.summary: TPR is SMALLEST because parallel resistances sum as 1/Rtotal = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + ... When vascular beds are in parallel, total resistance is LESS than any individual bed's resistance. Each organ bed has higher resistance than TPR.

whyCorrect.b: Total peripheral resistance is the SMALLEST because all vascular beds are arranged in PARALLEL. In parallel circuits, 1/Rtotal = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3... This makes total resistance LESS than any individual resistance.

whyIncorrect.a: Intestinal vascular bed resistance is HIGHER than TPR because it's just one parallel pathway. Individual organ resistances > TPR.
whyIncorrect.c: Renal vascular bed resistance is HIGHER than TPR - it's a single parallel branch.
whyIncorrect.d: Intracerebral vascular resistance is HIGHER than TPR.
whyIncorrect.e: Skin vessel resistance is HIGHER than TPR - especially at rest when skin vessels are constricted.

explanations.summary: Hemodynamics: (1) Capillary resistance < arteriolar due to massive parallel arrangement; (2) Veins (not aorta) have greatest compliance; (3) Velocity lowest at capillaries, not continuously decreasing; (4) Veins hold most blood, not capillaries; (5) Low viscosity increases turbulence (Re=ρvD/η); (6) Laminar flow fastest at axis.

whyCorrect.a: Capillary bed resistance < arteriolar despite small individual capillary diameter because MASSIVE parallelism (~10 billion capillaries) dramatically reduces total resistance.
whyCorrect.e: Reynolds number = ρvD/η. Lower viscosity (η) increases Re, making turbulence more likely (Re > 2000).
whyCorrect.f: In laminar flow, velocity profile is parabolic with MAXIMUM velocity at the center (axis) and zero at the vessel wall.

whyIncorrect.b: VEINS have greatest compliance (capacitance vessels), not aorta. Veins hold ~65% of blood volume.
whyIncorrect.c: Velocity does NOT decrease continuously - it's LOWEST at capillaries (large total cross-section), then INCREASES in veins.
whyIncorrect.d: VEINS contain largest blood volume (~65%), not capillaries (~5%). Veins are capacitance vessels.

explanations.summary: Poiseuille's Law: Flow = πΔPr⁴/8ηL. Radius has 4th power effect - doubling radius increases flow 16× (2⁴). Doubling pressure only doubles flow. Halving viscosity doubles flow. Radius is MOST effective.

whyCorrect.b: Doubling radius increases flow by 2⁴ = 16-fold (Poiseuille: Q ∝ r⁴). This is FAR more effective than any other change. Small vessel dilation has enormous flow effects.

whyIncorrect.a: Doubling pressure only doubles flow (Q ∝ ΔP). 2× increase, not 16×.
whyIncorrect.c: Halving viscosity doubles flow (Q ∝ 1/η). 2× increase, not 16×.
whyIncorrect.d: Halving radius DECREASES flow to 1/16 (0.5⁴ = 1/16). Opposite of what's needed.
whyIncorrect.e: Doubling length HALVES flow (Q ∝ 1/L). Wrong direction.
whyIncorrect.f: Halving length doubles flow. 2× increase, not 16×.
whyIncorrect.g: Doubling viscosity HALVES flow. Wrong direction.

explanations.summary: Turbulence occurs when Reynolds number > 2000. Re = ρvD/η. Turbulence favored by: larger vessel diameter (D↑), lower viscosity/hematocrit (η↓), higher velocity, sharp bends. NOT by high WBC or low velocity.

whyCorrect.b: Larger vessel caliber (diameter D) increases Reynolds number, promoting turbulence. Re = ρvD/η.
whyCorrect.c: Decreased hematocrit means lower blood viscosity (η↓), increasing Reynolds number and turbulence tendency.
whyCorrect.e: Sharp bends/angles disrupt laminar flow patterns and create turbulence even at lower Reynolds numbers.
whyCorrect.f: Low viscosity increases Reynolds number (Re ∝ 1/η), promoting turbulent flow.

whyIncorrect.a: Increased WBC (leukemia) INCREASES viscosity, which DECREASES turbulence tendency.
whyIncorrect.d: LOW velocity DECREASES Reynolds number, making flow MORE laminar, not turbulent.

explanations.summary: TPR = (P1-P2)/CO where P1=aortic pressure, P2=right atrial pressure, CO=cardiac output. This is Ohm's law for fluids: Resistance = Pressure difference / Flow. NOT CO/(P1-P2) or volume-based formulas.

whyCorrect.c: TPR = (P1-P2)/CO. Resistance = Pressure gradient / Flow. This is analogous to Ohm's law (R=V/I). Mean arterial pressure minus right atrial pressure divided by cardiac output.

whyIncorrect.a: CO/(P1-P2) is inverted - this would calculate conductance, not resistance.
whyIncorrect.b: V1-V2/CO uses volumes, not pressures. Resistance relates pressure to flow, not volume to flow.
whyIncorrect.d: V1-V2/P1-P2 is nonsensical - volume difference divided by pressure difference has no physiological meaning for resistance.

explanations.summary: Both TPR and pulmonary resistance are smallest because they represent parallel arrangements of many vascular beds. Individual organ beds (cerebral, intestinal, renal) have higher resistance than total parallel resistance.

whyCorrect.b: TPR is small because systemic beds are in PARALLEL - parallel resistances sum as reciprocals, making total less than any individual.
whyCorrect.c: Pulmonary circulation resistance is also very LOW (~1/10 of systemic TPR) because pulmonary vessels are wide, short, and highly compliant.

whyIncorrect.a: Intracerebral vascular bed is a single parallel branch - its resistance exceeds TPR.
whyIncorrect.d: Intestinal vascular bed resistance is higher than TPR.
whyIncorrect.e: Renal vascular bed resistance is higher than TPR, despite kidneys receiving 20% of CO.

explanations.summary: Poiseuille's Law: Resistance ∝ 1/r⁴ (inversely proportional to FOURTH power of radius). Small changes in radius cause dramatic resistance changes. Doubling radius decreases resistance 16-fold.

whyCorrect.c: Resistance is inversely proportional to the FOURTH power of radius (R ∝ 1/r⁴). From Poiseuille: R = 8ηL/πr⁴. This is why arteriolar tone is so powerful in controlling blood flow.

whyIncorrect.a: Inversely proportional to r² is wrong - it's r⁴, not r².
whyIncorrect.b: Directly proportional to radius is backwards - larger radius means LESS resistance.
whyIncorrect.d: Inversely proportional to r³ is wrong - it's r⁴.
whyIncorrect.e: Directly proportional to r² is doubly wrong - resistance DECREASES with radius and by 4th power, not 2nd.
